Detailed Description

Handle class which provides access to OBEX protocol data.

ObexObject instances provide shared access to OBEX protocol data stored within an internal ObexObjectData instance, which is managed employing shared reference-counting. Therefore assignment and copy-construction of ObexObject instances are cheap operations as only the handle is copied. These operations are also protected by an internal semaphore permitting to share object instances among multiple execution contexts. A special policy permits modification of an object only when it is not shared. Memory management is entirely performed by the handle class ObexObject, which provides Init() methods for creating virgin, unshared instances as well as a Release() method for invalidating the handle.

Constructor & Destructor Documentation

ObexObject::ObexObject (   ) 
 

Default constructor. Constructs an invalid ObexObject.

Init() must be called on the resulting object in order to make it valid. !

See also:
Init()

IsValid()

ObexObject::ObexObject (  ObexObject const &  from  ) 
 

Copy constructor.

Parameters:
from When 'from' refers to a valid ObexObject then the new object will becomes valid to and the reference count of the object is incremented, therefore the new object becomes a shared object, otherwise the newly created ObexObject becomes invalid, too.

ObexObject::~ObexObject (   ) 
 

Destructor.

Releases the ObexObjectData the current instance refers to, and destroys the current instance then.

Member Function Documentation

void ObexObject::CommitBuffer (  ObexBuffer &  source_buffer  ) 
 

Transfers ownership of the ObexBuffer to the ObexObject.

This takes the buffer ownership away from the source buffer !

Parameters:
source_buffer Valid ObexBuffer

UINT32 ObexObject::GetDataFractionSize (   )  const
 

Returns the size of the BODY data chunk contained in the object.

When the object instance is invalid or does not contain an ObexBuffer, '0' is returned. This method is mainly provided to support progress reporting which does not require direct access to the ObexBuffer.

ObexHeaderList & ObexObject::GetHeaderList (   )  const
 

Provides access to the internal list of OBEX headers.

UINT8 ObexObject::GetRequestFlags (   )  const
 

Returns the flags for an OBEX request.

Only used with CONNECT and SETPATH requests.

ObexObject::ResponseCode ObexObject::GetResponseCode (   )  const
 

Returns the response code of the operation in which the ObexObject was received.

ObexResult ObexObject::Init (  ResponseCode  response_code,
ObexBuffer &  source_buffer
) 
 

Initializes an ObexObject producing a valid object.

If the object is the only referrer of the internally managed data, it is reinitialized. This is cheaper than overwriting it with a freshly created one because a dynamic memory allocation is saved. If multiple or no referrers exist, a new ObexObjectData object is allocated. After a successful call to Init(), the freshly initialized object is referenced only once and therefore writable.

Parameters:
response_code OBEX response code or RespOk.
source_buffer ObexBuffer to construct ObexObject instance from, this will take ownership of the data buffer and render 'source_buffer' invalid.

ObexResult ObexObject::Init (  ResponseCode  response_code = Request  ) 
 

Initializes an ObexObject producing a valid object.

If the object is the only referrer of the internally managed data, it is reinitialized. This is cheaper than overwriting it with a freshly created one because a dynamic memory allocation is saved. If multiple or no referrers exist, a new ObexObjectData object is allocated. After a successful call to Init(), the freshly initialized object is referenced only once and therefore writable.

Parameters:
response_code OBEX response code or RespOk when a request object is to be constructed, 'Request' otherwise (default).
Returns:
ObexResult which evaluates to 'TRUE' in case of successful initialization, 'FALSE' otherwise.

BOOLEAN ObexObject::IsEndOfData (   )  const
 

Tells whether this is the last object containg data for the current OBEX operation.

BOOLEAN ObexObject::IsWritable (   )  const
 

Tells whether the object may be modified.

When this method returns 'FALSE', the object is shared and neither the object itself nor its header list may be modified. The only exception is ObtainBuffer(), which may be called also on a shared object.

BOOLEAN ObexObject::ObtainBuffer (  ObexBuffer &  target_buffer  ) 
 

Obtains ownership of the buffer from the OBEX object.

This takes the buffer ownership away from the OBEX object !

Parameters:
target_buffer ObexBuffer to be assigned the buffer from the OBEX object.
Returns:
'TRUE' if ownership of a valid buffer was acquired, 'FALSE' otherwise. Equivalent to checking IsValid() on the target_buffer after the calling the method.

ObexObject & ObexObject::operator= (  ObexObject const &  rhs  ) 
 

Assignment operator.

When the current instance is valid, the managed ObexObjectData instance is released first. Then the current instance becomes a referrer of the object denoted by 'rhs'. If 'rhs' is an invalid ObexObject, the current instance becomes invalid, too.

void ObexObject::Release (   ) 
 

Releases the reference to the internal body data.

This method will release the internally managed data and make the ObexObject become a 'virgin' handle again, just as if it had been constructed by the default constructor. You will loose access to all information previously store within the ObexObject. If no other referrers exist, the managed ObexObjectData instance is deleted, too.

void ObexObject::SetEndOfData (  BOOLEAN  end_of_data = TRUE  ) 
 

Sets the flag indicating end-of-data.

Caution: The object must be writable, otherwise this method will trigger an assertion. When in doubt, check IsWritable() first.

Depending on the context end-of-data can denote both a FINAL request (GET request) and indictate an END-OF-BODY header.

See also:
IsEndOfData()

void ObexObject::SetRequestFlags (  UINT8  req_flags  ) 
 

Sets the flags for an OBEX request.

Only used with CONNECT and SETPATH requests.

Caution: The object must be writable, otherwise this method will trigger an assertion. When in doubt, check IsWritable() first.

void ObexObject::SetResponseCode (  ResponseCode  r  ) 
 

Sets the response code of an obex operation.

Caution: The object must be writable, otherwise this method will trigger an assertion. When in doubt, check IsWritable() first.

Parameters:
r OBEX response code.
